page.title: 05SHEEP FARMING
page.content: SOME OF THE MAIN BREEDS IN OUR AREA ARE POL DORSETS, HORN DORSETS, MULES, TEXTEL AND MASHAMS. THE EWES BREED FOR ABOUT 6 YEARS AND ARE SLAUGHTERED AT 7. THE FARMERS HOPE FOR 2 LAMBS PER EWE PER YEAR BUT THE AVERAGE IS 1.6. MOST LAMBING IS IN APRIL ALTHOUGH ON A FEW FARMS IT TAKES PLACE IN NOVEMBER. NOVEMBER LAMBING MEANS THE LAMBS HAVE TO BE KEPT INDOORS IN WINTER. A BIG PROBLEM IN WINTER IS THE FREEZING OF STREAM WATER AND THE FARMER HAS TO CARRY BUCKETS OF WATER TO THE SHEEP HIMSELF. OTHER PROBLEMS INCLUDE THE DISEASE ORF WHICH CAUSES SCABS AROUND AND IN THE MOUTH, WHICH MAKES FEEDING DIFFICULT. THE AVERAGE SIZE OF A FARM IS 58 HECTARES AND THE AVERAGE NUMBER OF SHEEP IS 150. LAMBS ARE SLAUGHTERED 3 TO 4 MONTHS AFTER BIRTH. AT PRESENT SHEEP FARMING IS MORE PROFITABLE THAN ANY OTHER TYPE OF STOCK FARMING.
